bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love, August 6, 1952

div1.p: Hench writes that still has faith in Nogueira, but thinks the American Embassy in Cuba and the Surgeon General should become involved if it is discovered that the Cubans plan to dedicate Camp Lazear and Building No. 1 with new names.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love, August 6, 1952
div1.opener:
August 6, 1952
General Albert E. Love
2709 Wisconsin Avenue N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Love:
div1.p:
Due to a regrettable oversight on my part, I did not send to you the
enclosures. I sent them out a little hurriedly as I have been having,
the last two or three weeks, a rather voluminous and complicated correspondence
with Doctor Nogueira. I would appreciate it greatly if you would review,
or at least skim the enclosures at your earliest convenience and give me
any suggestions that you might have. Yesterday I sent a cable to Doctor
Nogueira asking specifically for a reply to my letters of July 7 and 26.
I still have real hopes of hearing from him. (He may be away on vacation
or he may be momentarily alone in his desire to make corrections, bucking
the others on the committee.) I still have faith in him and do not at this
time want to cross him up or “get others into the act” until he has had
every opportunity to straighten matters out himself. After all, he more
than any other man, has been responsible for the developments of the last
three or four years in behalf of Camp Lazear.

However if we find that he cannot make the appropriate corrections and if
we find that the Cubans plan to dedicate Camp Lazear with a new name, not
only for the camp but for Reed's Building No. 1, then I certainly think
that the American Embassy in Cuba and the Surgeon General himself should
know of the matter. Perhaps the Surgeon General's military representative
(I suppose he would be the Military Attache to the American Embassy there)
could make some discrete preliminary inquiries and then act politely, but
firmly, at the appropriate time. I am leaning heavily on you and Colonel
Siler for your advice in this matter.

Unfortunately for the matter concerned, I have long planned to take a vaca-
tion with my son and will be leaving Rochester on August 13 for Mexico;
however I will only be gone about two and a half or three weeks and even
from there I can write a few letters or send a few wires if necessary. I
believe the dedication is not until the latter part of September on the
occasion of the International Congress of Hygiene in Havana.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures:
1. Confidential letter of July 30 to a few “friends.”
2. Letter of July 26 to Dr. Nogueira
3. Enclosure re the volunteers.
4. Confidential letter of July 7 with addendum.
5. Excerpts from Havana Papers
6. Photographs of plans.
